data.title: The 1,000 Best Girl Baby Names
data.meta_description: Is there anything more fun (or overwhelming!) than hunting for the perfect name for your baby girl? Whether you’re looking to set your girl apart from the crowd in a big way or use something more recognizable, here are the top 1,000 baby girl names.
data.text:
Is there anything more fun (or overwhelming!) than hunting for the perfect name for your baby girl? With thousands and thousands of options out there, and each prettier than the last, we bet your list is pretty long. But fear not, because there is a list out there that is definitely much longer than yours, and we’ve got it right here.

Every year the Social Security Association puts out their long-awaited list of 1,000 most popular baby names, and the baby girl names other parents are picking are so much fun to browse. There are lots of flower and nature names (like Magnolia and River) on here, with elegant and vintage favorites scattered up and down the list. You’ll also notice many top names that can be shortened to Ellie, which is cool as elle is French for “she.”

The top 1,000 girl names include modern and gender-neutral picks, but the top 40 (detailed below with meanings) are trending uber-feminine and pretty. French and other European names having a major moment (Sophia, Isabelle) as are nature names (Willow, Lily, Aurora). And the letter y is prevalent right now to feminize neutral names (Madisyn, Londyn, Emersyn). If you’re starting from scratch, you’ll find lots of inspiration for both rare names and baby girl name trends.

Whether you’re looking to set your girl apart from the crowd in a big way or use something more recognizable, here are the top 1,000 baby girl names with special mention and details on America’s best of the best. Where do your favorite girl names fall?

Top 10 Best Girl Baby Names & Meanings

Olivia: It probably comes as no surprise to most that this pretty pick takes the top spot, as we all know at least a handful of Olivias age 10 and under, no? The Latin name meaning “olive tree” is just lovely.

Emma: In second position is a vintage girls’ name from the German translating to “universal.”

Charlotte: Sweet Char, Charlie, or Lottie will love her name that has pretty much always been popular since the naming charts began. The French name meaning “free man” remained well within the top 300, even during its lowest ranking years.

Amelia: With a soft sound and the strong meaning “work,” we love seeing her in the top 10!

Sophia: From the Greek, meaning “wisdom,” it’s a flowing yet understated name that’s been on the rise since the early 2000’s.

Mia: Meaning “mine” in Italian, it’s a gorgeous name bursting with love and pride for your little girl.

Isabella: More romantic vibes for our top names, featuring a four-syllable stunner that has Spanish/Italian origins (as a version of Elizabeth, “pledged to God”) and global appeal.

Ava: Number 8 has mixed origins (Hebrew, Latin, and Germanic) and an assortment of meanings so you can ascribe to it the one that feels like the best fit: “life; bird; or water/island.”

Evelyn: More vintage vibes for our top girl name list, this one means “desired” from the French and shares a German root with Ava for the alternate meaning “water/island.”

Luna: Your little “moon” child will grow beautifully into this soulful Italian baby girl name.

Best Girl Baby Names & Meanings: 11–25

Harper: You’re not alone if you feel like you woke up one day and this one was everywhere. English for “harp player,” the moniker was first known for feminine use by the novelist Harper Lee (for whom it was originally a surname).

Sofia: You’re not seeing double; the Spanish spelling of Sophia also ranks high!

Camila: Spanish from the Latin, meaning “young ceremonial attendant,” it’s a spirited name with vague nature ties (for its adjacency to the camellia flower).

Eleanor: More vintage adorableness is always welcome here. In the age of “cottagecore” and clogs, it should come as no surprise that an ancient French Provincial name is back in. Would you believe she ranked three spots higher in 2020 than she did in 1920?

Elizabeth: While the boys’ top 25 was loaded with classics like Henry and William, this name beloved for centuries is one of the few for the girls that you hear often now and throughout history. It means “pledged to God.”

Violet: This girl's name is anything but shrinking! In 2022 it bloomed from its spot at #35 all the way to #20…and then sprung to #16 in 2023!

Scarlett: There are three spelling variations in the top 1,000 girl names of this strikingly beautiful girls’ name that means “red.”

Emily: It’s been big since the 1980’s (and had been from the 1880’s to the 1960’s!) and shows no signs of slowing down soon. Meaning “rival” of Latin roots, it has fire to it, despite a soft and feminine sound.

Hazel: This color name that means "the hazelnut tree" evokes both a vintage vibe and an earthy quality. A baby name on the rise, Hazel cracked the top 20 in 2023!

Lily: This floral baby name has been inching its way up in recent years, and climbed 10 spots from #30 to #20 between 2022 and 2023!

Gianna: European names are ranking high at the moment, and this beaut from Italy is no exception. It translates to “the Lord is gracious,” as a shortened version of Giovanna.

Aurora: This lovely girl's name evokes both the dawn and the tale of Sleeping Beauty.

Penelope: This Greek baby girl name translates to “weaver” and offers up lots of fun nickname options like Penny, Nelly, Penel, and Poppy.

Aria: This melodic music-inspired name has been steadily gaining ground each year.

Nora: Meaning "honor" and "shining light," this popular Irish name is an unquestionably hopeful baby name.

Best Girl Baby Names & Meanings: 26–50

Chloe: This classic French name has been a staple in the top 20 in recent years.

Ellie: It's no surprise that this sweet diminutive of three blockbuster girls names (Eleanor, Ella, and Elizabeth) has staked out its own spot in the top 30!

Mila: The pretty girls’ name of Slavic/Russian roots means “gracious” or “dear.”

Avery: A gender-neutral name (ranking in the mid-200’s for boys), it has the adorable meaning “ruler of the elves.”

Layla: An anglicized, phonetic spelling of the Arabic name Leila, it means “night.”

Abigail: She might not have made the top 10, but don’t discount this old-fashioned feeling Hebrew name which translates adorably to “my father is joyful.” (Insert tearful-smiling emoji here!).

Ella: With mixed English and German roots meaning “fairy maiden” or “completely,” it’s a short and sweet name idea for a little girl.

Isla: Calling all jet-setters and water-lovers: Give your beachy babe a name that comes from the word "island."

Eliana: Between the El- names on the girls’ list and the popularity of Eli and Elijah on the boys’ list, it’s no surprise that this melodic version made the top 40! Meanings include “God has answered” and “sun.”

Nova: Nova means "new" which is apt for the novel baby name that's becoming a modern classic!

Madison: The English name meaning “son of Matthew” used to be more prevalent for boys, but is now out of the top 1,000 for that list and has been sitting pretty in the girls’ top names for over 20 years.

Zoe: With Greek roots, this name means life, and its alternate spelling (Zoey) isn't far behind at #51!

Ivy: This nature baby name has a Greek link too—it signifies faithfulness.

Grace: A gorgeous and timeless name with a meaning anyone would be thrilled for their little girl to embody.

Lucy: A fitting name for your bright young thing, Lucy means “light.”

Willow: A beautiful tribute to the elegant Willow tree, this name hails from Old English.

Emilia: A twist on the slightly more popular Amelia and Emily, Emilia means “eager” or “to excel.”

Riley: A gender-neutral name, this British moniker ranks significantly higher for girls than boys (#225).

Naomi: The classic Hebrew name means “beautiful” and “gentle.”

Victoria: A regal name that means to conquer.

Stella: Meaning "star" this baby name will perfectly suit the light of your life.

Elena: This Greek name is actually a version of Helen (which incidentally is much further down the list)!

Hannah: A timeless Hebrew name meaning “grace.”

Valentina: While the name certainly evokes the lovey-dovey holiday, its meaning is “strength” and “health.”

Maya: A multifacted name that has different meanings depending on its origin: In Greek, it means “good mother;” in Sanskrit it means “illusion;” and in Hebrew it means “water.”

About Jenny Studenroth Gerson

Jenny Studenroth Gerson is an Atlanta-based lifestyle journalist and novelist (Let Me Let You Go, 2020). Her work can be seen in publications including HuffPost, Cosmo, and WSJ, among many others. Jenny has researched thousands of baby names, combed through hundreds of nursery designs, and curated dozens of baby shower guides, making her absolutely the mom—and writer—you want to talk to when planning for Baby. When not meeting deadlines, she is chasing toddlers or chugging coffee—or both! Find her on Instagram @ourlifeinrosegold for mom hacks and more.

View more posts tagged, baby names

Disclaimer: The information on our site is NOT medical advice for any specific person or condition. It is only meant as general information. If you have any medical questions and concerns about your child or yourself, please contact your health provider.
